ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I definitely learned more about my own writing process as well as the different tools that are available to playwrights. Reading others' work was just as helpful as workshopping my own, and I think I definitely started to view playwriting as a conversational act because of how everyone's work influenced each other's.

This class balances studying previous works (mostly Off-Broadway short one-act plays) with workshopping new student-written material. By writing three short (10-30 page) plays throughout the semester, students learn more about their own writing style and receive helpful feedback.

Because this was a workshop seminar, I learned about the value of process, imperfection, and editing. We wrote 3 short plays over the course of the semester which also allowed me to further understand the different voices I have and stories that I can tell.

THST 321 was my first college-level playwriting course, and the expertise of someone like Professor Jacobs-Jenkins was invaluable. He was detail-oriented and interrogative when giving feedback on our works, but he always prompted us to trust our instincts and to let our choices guide the trajectory of each play. I feel I'm walking away from this course knowing what sort of questions I have to ask of myself (and others) in strengthening my dramatic writing. Additionally, while this course focused on short plays, it undoubtedly laid a framework for the production of longer works.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course was very strong as a workshop, but I wish that we had more writing exercises in class like the ones we did on the first day. I think short assignments like those would keep things interesting and help to find ways into our longer assignments.

This class has such an emphasis on student voice and work, which definitely is a strength in terms of growth and learning. Structurally, the class is organized around each student having three workshops, writing one new short play for each. This is super unique compared to other playwriting classes offered at Yale, which normally have you workshop bits and pieces from just one long play that you write all semester. This three short play structure emphasizes experimentation, improvement, and a 'work-in-progress'/first draft mindset, which is all so important to becoming a better playwright.

I see no major weaknesses of this course. It was a deeply enjoyable, intimate seminar that achieved an admirable balance of workshopping, focus on texts by professional playwrights, and analysis/discussion of media in general, which synthesized very effectively.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am very glad that we didn't do Zoom readings of our plays. I think omitting that part of a typical workshop was definitely the right move in a virtual format.
Since the class was all discussion-based, it was really easy to do over Zoom!

I appreciated the way in which Professor Jacobs-Jenkins would "invite us" to unmute at the start of each class, which helped break down a bit of the artificial barrier that Zoom inherently constructs, and allowed the seminar to feel more natural and comfortable.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This class was a wonderful environment to experiment with playwriting, even though it was online. Especially if this class continues to have a small enrollment cap, I would 10/10 recommend.
I highly recommend this course to anyone with a background in playwriting looking to further develop their skills by reading unique work and growing through an in-depth workshop process.
Yes! It challenged me to be playful with my work and think infinitely.

Any student interested in storytelling, but especially playwriting, would likely enjoy THST 321. While the readings did often fall into similar subgenres, students had complete freedom of choice when it came to writing their own plays, which was much appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a virtual seminar
